etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Burthogge (bap. 1638, d. 1705), philosopher. As adjective from (i) post-classical Latin heureticus inventive

definitions: Of or relating to discovery or invention.

notes.text: In later use frequently with reference to the works of the philosopher C. S. Peirce or the critical theorist G. L. Ulmer.
